How are the current, far-reaching easing of restrictions affecting university and college operations?  Not directly. Because the universities and colleges remain exempt from the general health law requirements and thus also from the current Corona Basic Measures Ordinance . However, they offer an important orientation for the individual and independent definition of those corona measures that the universities and colleges take independently and independently within the framework of their autonomy. These vary from university to university and from college to college.    This is also the reason why universities and colleges currently have different forms of access regulations (2.5G, 3G regulation or none at all) depending on their situation-specific requirements and why the handling of a mask requirement is quite different. In view of the general lifting of most restrictions, universities and colleges are also considering whether they should relax their corona measures even further, while also monitoring the epidemiological situation. In any case, the recommendation to wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms remains.    Therefore, please find out from your respective university or college which corona measures must be observed at their locations. Change in testing strategy as of 1 April 2022.  The adjustment of the test strategy affects the previously free mass testing. In the future, 5 free PCR and 5 free antigen tests will be available to every citizen per month.    **New guidelines**  Test strategy  Austria is broadly positioned in terms of testing the population and has been able to establish a secure, functioning and nationwide test network. In order to be prepared for the coming challenges, the basic features of this test system should be retained. This means that new developments such as new virus variants can be reacted to    quickly if necessary .    At the same time, Austria is currently facing changed framework conditions due to the Omicron variant. Therefore, the Austrian test strategy - as a key pillar of pandemic management - is being adapted to the current situation: Against the background of higher immunity in the population, tests should now be used primarily where they are needed. Also, anyone who needs a test will get one! This means that tests for symptomatic people as well as tests for residents, visitors and employees of vulnerable areas will continue to be available free of charge and without restrictions.    Starting in April, the Austrian test strategy consists of three different test tracks. Funding will be provided by the federal government, but implementation and organization will remain the responsibility of the federal states, as has been the case up to now.    Symptomatic Individuals : Tests for symptomatic individuals will remain in place as usual. This means that the tests are still available free of charge and without restrictions for this group of people.     The first point of contact for symptomatic people remains 1450. The exact implementation is carried out by the individual federal states, which is why the process for those affected can vary from federal state to federal state.    Vulnerable Settings : The new test regulation defines vulnerable areas, for whose residents, visitors and employees as well as for companions and external service providers unlimited and free tests will continue to be available.  Here, too, implementation is carried out by the federal states.      Tests of the general public ("mass testing") : The adjustment of the test strategy affects the previously free mass testing. In the future, 5 free PCR and 5 free antigen tests will be available to every citizen per month :  5 PCR tests: starting April 1st.  5 antigen tests: Available from pharmacies from April 9th.  A temporary solution is provided for self-tests purchased before April 1st: Each person can have a total of 10 PCR tests evaluated by April 30th.  For all additional tests, the chargeable test offer in Austria can be used.    At the same time, wastewater monitoring will play a greater role in the future in order to be able to reliably and long-term monitor the course of the pandemic.    The adjusted test strategy will come into effect on April 1st and will initially be valid until June 30th.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220403154843/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

In order to be prepared for the coming challenges, the basic features of this test system should be retained. This means that new developments such as new virus variants can be reacted to quickly if necessary.    At the same time, Austria is currently facing changed framework conditions due to the Omicron variant. Therefore, the Austrian test strategy - as a key pillar of pandemic management - is being adapted to the current situation: Against the background of higher immunity in the population, tests should now be used primarily where they are needed. Also, anyone who needs a test will get one! This means that tests for symptomatic people as well as tests for residents, visitors and employees of vulnerable areas will continue to be available free of charge and without restrictions.    Starting in April, the Austrian test strategy consists of three different test tracks. Funding will be provided by the federal government, but implementation and organization will remain the responsibility of the federal states, as has been the case up to now.    1.	Symptomatic Individuals : Tests for symptomatic individuals will remain in place as usual. This means that the tests are still available free of charge and without restrictions for this group of people.   The first point of contact for symptomatic people remains 1450. The exact implementation is carried out by the individual federal states, which is why the process for those affected can vary from federal state to federal state.    2.	Vulnerable Settings : The new test regulation defines vulnerable areas, for whose residents, visitors and employees as well as for companions and external service providers unlimited and free tests will continue to be available.  Here, too, implementation is carried out by the federal states.      3.	Tests of the general public ("mass testing") : The adjustment of the test strategy affects the previously free mass testing. In the future, 5 free PCR and 5 free antigen tests will be available to every citizen per month :  0.	5 PCR tests: starting April 1st.  1.	5 antigen tests: available from pharmacies.  2.	A temporary solution is provided for self-tests purchased before April 1st: Each person can have a total of 10 PCR tests evaluated by April 30th.    For all additional tests, you can use the chargeable test offer in Austria.  At the same time, wastewater monitoring will play a greater role in the future in order to be able to reliably and long-term monitor the course of the pandemic.  The adjusted test strategy came into effect on April 1st and is initially valid until June 30th. No contact persons are:  â¢	Persons if FFP 2 masks were worn on both sides during contact,  â¢	Persons with 3 immunological events ( e.g. 3 vaccinations),  â¢	Children up to 12 years of age with 2 immunological events, or  â¢	People who have recovered within the last 3 months (omicron recoveries).     Traffic Restriction:  â¢	Wearing an  FFP 2 mask  or a higher-quality mask when in contact with other people, even within private living areas,  â¢	No visits to facilities with vulnerable people or risky settings ( e.g. retirement homes, health facilities),  â¢	No entry into facilities  or no exercise of activities where  an FFP 2 mask  or an MNS is not worn  continuously  (catering establishments, fitness clubs , etc. ),  â¢	No attendance of major events and the like (sporting events, concerts, etc.)    Visiting the place of work is generally possible, provided that the continuous wearing of an  FFP 2 mask and compliance with suitable protective measures can be guaranteed. Have sanctioned and sanction the law whose content follows, which the National Council adopted in its session of September 14, 2021.    First article.    Is required to be vaccinated against COVID-19:    1) any staff member:       a) a care or health establishment;       b) an establishment, service or organization whose specific mission is to welcome, supervise or accommodate people aged at least 60 or dependent people;       c) an establishment, service or organization whose specific mission is to welcome, supervise or accommodate people with disabilities;    2) any person who, without being a staff member of one of the establishments, services or organizations mentioned in point 1), carries out an activity there, including as a volunteer, pupil or student, when is in direct contact with people whom it welcomes, supervises or accommodates, with the exception of those who occasionally carry out this activity without being in direct contact with people whom they welcome, supervise or accommodate;    3) any person who practices one of the following health professions:         a) doctor;         b) dental surgeon;         c) midwife;         d) pharmacist or pharmacy assistant;         e) medical assistant;         f) osteopath;    4) any non-medical staff carrying out their activity with one of the professionals mentioned in point 3) when they are in direct contact with the patients of these professionals;    5) any member of the fire brigade corps;    6) any person carrying out a home help activity with people aged at least 60, dependent people or disabled people;    7) any person carrying out a medical transport activity.    The vaccination obligation provided for in the first paragraph is complied with when the person justifies, in accordance with the provisions of Articles 3 and 4, the complete vaccination schedule for one of the vaccines against COVID-19 by means of proof considered as attesting to the satisfaction of said scheme.    The vaccination obligation defined in this article is also applicable to persons temporarily unable to perform their duties as a result of a duly confirmed illness. However, it does not apply to persons on maternity leave, long-term sick leave, long-term sick leave or disability.    A ministerial decree sets the terms of application of this article, in particular the definition of the complete vaccination schedule and the conditions to justify it.    Art. 2.    The person presenting either:    1) a certificate of confirmation of medical contraindication to vaccination against COVID-19 issued by a committee of doctors on the basis of a medical certificate specifying and justifying a contraindication to this temporary or permanent vaccination;    2) a valid certificate of recovery following contamination by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. On the expiry date of this certificate, the person concerned presents a complete vaccination schedule of one of the vaccines against COVID-19.    The methods of application of this article are fixed by ministerial order.    Art. 3.    Any person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1 informs his employer, within seven days of the latter's request, of the fact that he has satisfied it or is not subject to it, justifying the case where applicable, of his complete vaccination schedule or of one of the exemptions mentioned in Article 2.    When he does not wish to transmit them himself to his employer for the application of the preceding paragraph, the person may transmit the document certifying that he has carried out a complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of counter - indication to the Office of Occupational Medicine, which informs the employer, without delay, of the satisfaction of the vaccination obligation, as defined by articles 1 and 2.    When, in application of the preceding paragraphs, a certificate of reinstatement has been transmitted to the Office of Occupational Medicine, the latter informs the person, one month before the occurrence of the expiry of the said certificate, that he must, on the date expiry date, present either a complete vaccination schedule for one of the vaccines against COVID-19, or one of the documents mentioned in article 2.    In the absence of justification, either of this plan, or of the certificate of reinstatement or the certificate of confirmation of contraindication mentioned in article 2, this person may use, with the agreement of his employer, days off paid or compensatory rest. If he does not use them or if, after having used them, he does not justify his complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of contraindication, this person is, by the effect of this law , suspended from duty. His employer notifies him of this legal suspension by any means.    When this suspension lasts for more than a week, the person is called by his employer to an interview in order to examine his situation with him.    The person's remuneration is maintained at fifty percent during the first four weeks of the suspension. The sums paid for the payment of the remuneration thus maintained and the related social security contributions are reimbursed to the employer by the State.    At the end of this period, no remuneration is maintained.    During the first four weeks of the suspension, no dismissal can be pronounced due to the inability to occupy the job due to non-compliance with the vaccination obligation provided for by article 1.    At the end of a period of four weeks of suspension and until the expiry of a period of twelve weeks of suspension, the employer may, unless the person objects, depending on the case, either:    - pronouncing the dismissal of the person, without notice, because of his inability to occupy his job, if he is unable to offer him another job. In this case, the payment of the dismissal indemnity is reimbursed to the employer by the State;    - pronouncing the automatic transfer of the person to a position which is not subject to the vaccination obligation provided for by this law or, failing that, his retirement when his pension rights are open.    In the event of opposition, the person remains suspended from his duties either until the satisfaction of the vaccination obligation provided for by this law, or until the termination of the employment relationship, without the provisions of the preceding paragraph not are applicable.    The suspension ends automatically when the person proves his complete vaccination schedule, the recovery certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in article 2. This person informs his employer, who has a period of seven days to proceed with his reinstatement.    When a person's fixed-term employment contract is suspended pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraphs, this contract ends at the scheduled term if the latter occurs during the suspension period.    The suspension provided for in this article entails suspension of the reciprocal obligations between the person and the employer. During the aforementioned period of twelve weeks, it does not entail the suspension of benefits in kind of health insurance, family benefits, social benefits, allowances or pensions to which the person is entitled, for himself and his beneficiaries, on the date of its suspension.    The suspension cannot be assimilated to a period of effective work for the determination of paid leave as well as for the legal and contractual rights acquired by the person in respect of his seniority. However, this suspension is assimilated to a period of actual work for the determination of these leaves and these rights for the first twelve weeks of suspension, when it ends with the reinstatement of the person.    The employer may keep the results of the verifications of satisfaction of the obligations provided for by this law, until the end of its application.    The employer ensures the secure storage of these documents and, at the end of the application of the law, the proper destruction of the latter.    Art. 3-1.    When the person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for by this law holds a certificate confirming the medical contraindication to vaccination against COVID-19, the employer may, with his agreement, assign him, even temporarily, to another position. In the absence of agreement, the person is maintained in his post. It must, in all cases, observe reinforced health measures as provided for by ministerial order.    Art. 3-2.    Any person subject to the vaccination obligation pursuant to number 2 of article 1, informs the person in charge of the establishment, service or organization within which he exercises his activity, within seven days of the request for the latter, because she has complied with it or is not subject to it, justifying, where applicable, her complete vaccination schedule or one of the exemptions mentioned in Article 2.    When he does not wish to send them himself to the person responsible for the application of the preceding paragraph, the person can send the document certifying that he has carried out a complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of counter-indication to the Director of Health Action, who immediately informs the head of the establishment, service or organization in which the person carries out his activity of the satisfaction of the vaccination obligation, such as defined by Articles 1 and 2.    When, in application of the preceding paragraphs, a certificate of recovery has been sent to the Director of Health Action, the latter informs the person, one month before the occurrence of the expiry of the said certificate, that he must, on the date of expiry of this certificate, present a complete vaccination schedule of one of the vaccines against COVID-19.    In the absence of justification by the person of this plan, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of contraindication mentioned in article 2, this person in charge refuses the person access to the establishment, service or body. until she presented him with this justification.    Art. 4.    When a person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1 exercises his professional activity on a liberal or self-employed basis, he informs the Director of Health Action, within seven days of the latter's request, of the fact that she has complied with it or is not subject to it, justifying, where applicable, her complete vaccination schedule or one of the exemptions mentioned in Article 2.    When, pursuant to the preceding paragraph, a certificate of recovery has been sent to the Director of Health Action, the latter informs the person, one month before the expiry of the said certificate, that he must, on the date of expiry of this, present either a complete vaccination schedule for one of the vaccines against COVID-19, or one of the documents mentioned in article 2.    In the absence of justification for this scheme, the reinstatement certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in Article 2, the competent administrative authority shall pronounce the administrative suspension applicable to the activity of this person. The said authority notifies him of this decision by any means.    When this suspension lasts for more than a week, the person is summoned by the said authority to an interview in order to examine his situation with him.    During the first twelve weeks of suspension, this does not lead to the suspension of affiliation to the sickness, accident and maternity insurance fund for self-employed workers.    The suspension ends automatically when the person proves his complete vaccination schedule, the recovery certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in article 2.    Art. 4-1.    The person referred to in the previous article, holder of a contraindication confirmation certificate referred to in article 2, may continue to carry out his activity while respecting reinforced health measures as provided for by ministerial order. This person is required to inform his patients or clients of his medical contraindication to vaccination.    Art. 5.    Without prejudice to the actions that could be exercised under ordinary law, the State bears the compensation for any damage directly attributable to any vaccination against COVID-19, regularly carried out on Monegasque territory, of a person mentioned in Article 1 .    Up to the amount of the indemnity it has paid, the State is, if necessary, subrogated in the rights and actions of the victim against those responsible for the damage.    Art. 6.    The employer of a person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1 cannot impose any disciplinary sanction based on a lack of vaccination against COVID-19.    When a person subject to this vaccination obligation comes under a professional order, no disciplinary sanction based on a lack of vaccination against COVID-19 can be pronounced by the disciplinary courts of this order.    Art. 7.    Is punished with the fine provided for in number 3 of article 29 of the Penal Code:    1) anyone who is subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1, either:       a) fails to issue the information provided for in the first paragraph of Article 3 within seven days following the request of his employer;       b) fails to issue the information provided for, as the case may be, in Article 3-2 or Article 4, within seven days of the request made to it;       c) does not provide proof of his complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of the contraindication mentioned in article 2, after having informed, as the case may be, his employer, the Office of Occupational Medicine or the head of the establishment, service or organization mentioned in Article 3-2 or the Director of Health Action, that he is vaccinated or that he benefits from one of the said certificates;    2) the employer who is:         a) recruits, for a job falling within the scope of the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1, a person without the latter having previously provided proof of their complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of counter- indication mentioned in article 2;         b) does not implement the legal suspension of his duties of a member of his staff subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1 when, seven days after having asked him to deliver the information provided for in article 3, this member has not provided proof of his complete vaccination schedule, the recovery certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in article 2;    3) the person in charge of an establishment, service or organization mentioned in Article 1 who does not refuse access to this establishment, service or organization to a person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for by article 1, when the latter has not previously justified its complete vaccination schedule, the recovery certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in article 2.    Art. 8.    The provisions of this law enter into force on October 30, 2021.    As of this date, persons subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1, who, within the framework of a vaccination schedule comprising several doses, justify the administration of at least one of the required doses must present a complete vaccination schedule no later than December 7, 2021.    The vaccination obligation provided for by article 1 applies for a period of eighteen months following the entry into force of this law. This obligation may, however, cease to apply before the expiry of this period, as soon as the exceptional measures to combat the COVID-19 epidemic relating to the quarantine or isolation of persons taken by the Minister of State, provided for by the ministerial decision of February 24, 2020, as amended, cease to have effect.    This Act is enacted and shall be enforced as law of the State.    Done at Our Palace in Monaco, on September twenty, two thousand and twenty-one.

A ministerial decree sets the terms of application of this article, in particular the definition of the complete vaccination schedule and the conditions to justify it.    Art. 2.    The person presenting either:    1) a certificate of confirmation of medical contraindication to vaccination against COVID-19 issued by a committee of doctors on the basis of a medical certificate specifying and justifying a contraindication to this temporary or permanent vaccination;    2) a valid certificate of recovery following contamination by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. On the expiry date of this certificate, the person concerned presents a complete vaccination schedule of one of the vaccines against COVID-19.    The methods of application of this article are fixed by ministerial order.    Art. 3.    Any person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1 informs his employer, within seven days of the latter's request, of the fact that he has satisfied it or is not subject to it, justifying the case where applicable, of his complete vaccination schedule or of one of the exemptions mentioned in Article 2. When, in application of the preceding paragraphs, a certificate of reinstatement has been transmitted to the Office of Occupational Medicine, the latter informs the person, one month before the occurrence of the expiry of the said certificate, that he must, on the date expiry date, present either a complete vaccination schedule for one of the vaccines against COVID-19, or one of the documents mentioned in article 2.    In the absence of justification, either of this plan, or of the certificate of reinstatement or the certificate of confirmation of contraindication mentioned in article 2, this person may use, with the agreement of his employer, days off paid or compensatory rest. If he does not use them or if, after having used them, he does not justify his complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of contraindication, this person is, by the effect of this law , suspended from duty. His employer notifies him of this legal suspension by any means.    When this suspension lasts for more than a week, the person is called by his employer to an interview in order to examine his situation with him.    The person's remuneration is maintained at fifty percent during the first four weeks of the suspension. The sums paid for the payment of the remuneration thus maintained and the related social security contributions are reimbursed to the employer by the State.    At the end of this period, no remuneration is maintained.    During the first four weeks of the suspension, no dismissal can be pronounced due to the inability to occupy the job due to non-compliance with the vaccination obligation provided for by article 1.    At the end of a period of four weeks of suspension and until the expiry of a period of twelve weeks of suspension, the employer may, unless the person objects, depending on the case, either:    - pronouncing the dismissal of the person, without notice, because of his inability to occupy his job, if he is unable to offer him another job. In this case, the payment of the dismissal indemnity is reimbursed to the employer by the State;    - pronouncing the automatic transfer of the person to a position which is not subject to the vaccination obligation provided for by this law or, failing that, his retirement when his pension rights are open.    In the event of opposition, the person remains suspended from his duties either until the satisfaction of the vaccination obligation provided for by this law, or until the termination of the employment relationship, without the provisions of the preceding paragraph not are applicable.    The suspension ends automatically when the person proves his complete vaccination schedule, the recovery certificate or the contraindication confirmation certificate mentioned in article 2. This person informs his employer, who has a period of seven days to proceed with his reinstatement. The employer may keep the results of the verifications of satisfaction of the obligations provided for by this law, until the end of its application. When the person subject to the vaccination obligation provided for by this law holds a certificate confirming the medical contraindication to vaccination against COVID-19, the employer may, with his agreement, assign him, even temporarily, to another position. When, pursuant to the preceding paragraph, a certificate of recovery has been sent to the Director of Health Action, the latter informs the person, one month before the expiry of the said certificate, that he must, on the date of expiry of this, present either a complete vaccination schedule for one of the vaccines against COVID-19, or one of the documents mentioned in article 2.    2) the employer who is:         a) recruits, for a job falling within the scope of the vaccination obligation provided for in Article 1, a person without the latter having previously provided proof of their complete vaccination schedule, the certificate of recovery or the certificate of confirmation of counter- indication mentioned in article 2; Effective January 17, 2022, Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.  Anyone required to self-isolate should complete an online epidemiological card 3 days before arriving in Moldova.  Exceptions to the entry rules above are made for the following categories of persons if they do not show clinical signs of respiratory infection or fever:  1) children up to 12 years of age; 2) students up to 18 years age going to study or travel for activities related to completing/ organizing/conducting/ participating in international competitions; 3) persons travelling for health reasons, including accompanying persons with appropriate documentation; 4) passengers in transit (24 hours transiting Moldova), the transit itinerary to be established by the Border Police; 4) persons who are summoned by courts/law enforcement as well as their legal representatives with appropriate documentation; 5) holders of diplomatic, service, official and special passports, as well as holders of Laissez-Passer travel documents issued by the United Nations, including family members of diplomatic and consular missions, and international organizations/missions accredited to the Republic of Moldova.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220416101520/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html
